payload.instructions:
# Agent Notes

- To run the OS in QEMU, use `make run-hdd`.
  - Prefer this over `make run`; the HDD target is the intended path for interactive runs.
- If you run `make run-hdd`, you won't be able to continue, because the process won't finish.  If you want to run it then kill it to get serial output, run `killall qemu-system-x86_64`
- Standard build remains `make` (produces `os.img` and `hdd.img`).
- We have our own libc implementation (src/kernel/libc.c), and memory/heap management (malloc, calloc, realloc, free) in src/kernel/heap.c.  Use heap operations rather than trying to use fixed memory assigned in stage2.asm unless absolutely necessary.
- If you need to modify memory layout, make sure you keep STAGE2_BASE and STACK_TOP up-to-date to avoid smashing memory through overlaps in stage2.asm
- If you want to boot the kernel, the shell has a variety of commands (including shutdown) - which you can use to stop the kernel and return to your thinking

Thanks!

content.text:
<user_instructions>

# Agent Notes

- To run the OS in QEMU, use `make run-hdd`.
  - Prefer this over `make run`; the HDD target is the intended path for interactive runs.
- If you run `make run-hdd`, you won't be able to continue, because the process won't finish.  If you want to run it then kill it to get serial output, run `killall qemu-system-x86_64`
- Standard build remains `make` (produces `os.img` and `hdd.img`).
- We have our own libc implementation (src/kernel/libc.c), and memory/heap management (malloc, calloc, realloc, free) in src/kernel/heap.c.  Use heap operations rather than trying to use fixed memory assigned in stage2.asm unless absolutely necessary.
- If you need to modify memory layout, make sure you keep STAGE2_BASE and STACK_TOP up-to-date to avoid smashing memory through overlaps in stage2.asm
- If you want to boot the kernel, the shell has a variety of commands (including shutdown) - which you can use to stop the kernel and return to your thinking

Thanks!



</user_instructions>

## My request for Codex:
Please make a few 'quality of life' changes:

1. In the text shell and the video vt100 emulator, make up arrow/down arrow recall previous commands (up to the last 20) like in bash

2. In the video terminal (atk_shell / atk_terminal), after I type enough characters to fill a line and it scrolls to the next line, if I press backspace, it doesn't go back to the previous line again (it just stops at the first character of the new line and goes no further.

3. Userland procsesses don't inherit the current path from a shell - for example, if I'm in /mnt/disk1 (which contains SF-Pro.ttf), I should be able to do "runelf ttf_demo.elf SF-Pro.ttf", but instead currently I have to do "runelf ttf_demo.elf /mnt/disk1/SF-Pro.ttf"

payload.arguments: {"plan":[{"step":"Inspect shell/terminal input handling and current cwd propagation to understand integration points","status":"in_progress"},{"step":"Implement shared command history (20 entries) for text shell and VT100 video shell","status":"pending"},{"step":"Fix video terminal backspace so it traverses previous line after wrapping/scrolling","status":"pending"},{"step":"Ensure user processes inherit the shellâ€™s current working directory when launched","status":"pending"}]}

payload.text:
**Analyzing backspace behavior across lines**

I'm tracing how backspace handles cursor movement, especially when at column zero but not the first row, and how scrolling affects this. Thereâ€™s nuance in the cursor row after line feeds and scrolls since content shifts upward, so deleting the previous character means moving to the correct line and column. Iâ€™m working through edge cases involving manually inserted newlines, auto-wraps, and whether backspace should cross lines or stop. Next, Iâ€™ll update `terminal_backspace` to support moving back across lines properly when `cursor_col == 0` and consider command history integration for the text shell and vt100 emulator.

summary.text:
**Analyzing backspace behavior across lines**

I'm tracing how backspace handles cursor movement, especially when at column zero but not the first row, and how scrolling affects this. Thereâ€™s nuance in the cursor row after line feeds and scrolls since content shifts upward, so deleting the previous character means moving to the correct line and column. Iâ€™m working through edge cases involving manually inserted newlines, auto-wraps, and whether backspace should cross lines or stop. Next, Iâ€™ll update `terminal_backspace` to support moving back across lines properly when `cursor_col == 0` and consider command history integration for the text shell and vt100 emulator.

payload.text:
**Planning per-process current working directory**

Iâ€™m figuring out how to have each process track its own current working directory by adding a cwd pointer to the process struct and syncing it when the shell launches user processes so they inherit the shellâ€™s current path. I want to make sure the cwd is properly initialized, managed, and accessible through new getter/setter functions. Next, Iâ€™ll dive into how the shell runs user processes to hook this up.

I want to make sure the cwd is properly initialized, managed, and accessible through new getter/setter functions. Next, Iâ€™ll dive into how the shell runs user processes to hook this up.

payload.output: {"output":"src/kernel/process.c:1984:process_t *process_create_user_elf_with_parent(const char *name,\n","metadata":{"exit_code":0,"duration_seconds":0.3}}

payload.text:
**Planning process current working directory support**

I'm mapping out how to add a current working directory field to processes, needing to include `vfs.h` and add getter/setter functions in `process.h`. I'll make sure new processes inherit their parent's cwd or default to root, handling kernel and user processes properly. To confirm this setup, I'll check the boot sequence to ensure VFS initializes before processes get their cwd set.

summary.text:
**Planning process current working directory support**

I'm mapping out how to add a current working directory field to processes, needing to include `vfs.h` and add getter/setter functions in `process.h`. I'll make sure new processes inherit their parent's cwd or default to root, handling kernel and user processes properly. To confirm this setup, I'll check the boot sequence to ensure VFS initializes before processes get their cwd set.

payload.text:
**Designing process current directory handling**

I'm considering how to handle per-process current directories when the virtual filesystem may not be initialized yet. I'll set process cwd to NULL initially if created before vfs_init, then fallback to root dynamically when accessed. Also, processes created after vfs_init will inherit parent's cwd or root. I want to ensure the shell's cwd changes propagate to the process so child processes inherit correct directoriesâ€”I'll check how the shell command `cd` updates state to integrate that with the process cwd.

summary.text:
**Designing process current directory handling**

I'm considering how to handle per-process current directories when the virtual filesystem may not be initialized yet. I'll set process cwd to NULL initially if created before vfs_init, then fallback to root dynamically when accessed. Also, processes created after vfs_init will inherit parent's cwd or root. I want to ensure the shell's cwd changes propagate to the process so child processes inherit correct directoriesâ€”I'll check how the shell command `cd` updates state to integrate that with the process cwd.

payload.text:
**Planning process cwd synchronization**

Iâ€™m mapping out how to keep the processâ€™s current working directory in sync with the shellâ€™s cwd, so user processes open files relative to their own cwd. This involves adding functions to get and set the process cwd, updating `shell_cmd_cd` to update the current process, and modifying syscalls to use the process cwd. I also want to ensure the cwd pointer stays valid and only directories are set as cwd. Next, Iâ€™ll check the VFS node reference handling to confirm this approach.

summary.text:
**Planning process cwd synchronization**

Iâ€™m mapping out how to keep the processâ€™s current working directory in sync with the shellâ€™s cwd, so user processes open files relative to their own cwd. This involves adding functions to get and set the process cwd, updating `shell_cmd_cd` to update the current process, and modifying syscalls to use the process cwd. I also want to ensure the cwd pointer stays valid and only directories are set as cwd. Next, Iâ€™ll check the VFS node reference handling to confirm this approach.

payload.text:
**Extending terminal input with history and arrow key handling**

Iâ€™m planning to add a history buffer with a ring structure to store previous input lines, carefully managing dynamic strings and limiting memory overhead by activating these features only when the terminal is interactive. Iâ€™ll implement a small state machine to detect arrow key escape sequences, enabling users to navigate command history by clearing and replacing the current input line, handling multi-line input with precise backspacing and cursor control. This approach keeps the terminal flexible for both interactive and log-only use cases.

This approach keeps the terminal flexible for both interactive and log-only use cases.

payload.output: Plan updated

payload.text:
**Planning keyboard and shell history changes**

I'm preparing to add arrow key sequence handling in the keyboard driver to support CLI history navigation and to implement command history storage and navigation in the shell. This involves managing pending key sequences in the keyboard code and creating history buffers and navigation helpers in the shell code, all while making sure input flow and command recording integrate smoothly.

summary.text:
**Planning keyboard and shell history changes**

I'm preparing to add arrow key sequence handling in the keyboard driver to support CLI history navigation and to implement command history storage and navigation in the shell. This involves managing pending key sequences in the keyboard code and creating history buffers and navigation helpers in the shell code, all while making sure input flow and command recording integrate smoothly.

payload.text:
**Designing command history with navigation**

I'm mapping out how to record shell commands into history only when non-empty, trimming inputs carefully, and skipping deduplication to match typical shell behavior. To support command recall, I'm planning escape sequence parsing for arrow keys by implementing non-blocking input reads and building a robust interface for navigating history entries in the CLI line editor. This includes careful buffer management for live command edits and properly handling edge cases with ESC key inputs.

**Planning saved-line handling for history navigation**

I'm laying out how to save the current command line when history navigation starts and restore it when navigation ends, mimicking typical shell behavior so that edits to recalled commands don't lose the original input. This involves tracking a saved buffer alongside cursor position and adapting both CLI and atk_terminal history mechanisms to support this seamless user experience with arrow key navigation.

**Implementing keyboard pending queue for arrow keys**

I'm preparing to insert a pending character queue in the keyboard driver to output escape sequences for arrow keys. This will let me enqueue full sequences and emit them one character at a time on consecutive reads, ensuring arrow keys are properly handled even though their scancode maps to zero.

summary.text:
**Designing command history with navigation**

I'm mapping out how to record shell commands into history only when non-empty, trimming inputs carefully, and skipping deduplication to match typical shell behavior. To support command recall, I'm planning escape sequence parsing for arrow keys by implementing non-blocking input reads and building a robust interface for navigating history entries in the CLI line editor. This includes careful buffer management for live command edits and properly handling edge cases with ESC key inputs.

**Planning saved-line handling for history navigation**

I'm laying out how to save the current command line when history navigation starts and restore it when navigation ends, mimicking typical shell behavior so that edits to recalled commands don't lose the original input. This involves tracking a saved buffer alongside cursor position and adapting both CLI and atk_terminal history mechanisms to support this seamless user experience with arrow key navigation.

**Implementing keyboard pending queue for arrow keys**

I'm preparing to insert a pending character queue in the keyboard driver to output escape sequences for arrow keys. This will let me enqueue full sequences and emit them one character at a time on consecutive reads, ensuring arrow keys are properly handled even though their scancode maps to zero.

payload.text:
**Designing shell command history support**

I'm planning extensive additions to shell.c to implement command history with navigation via arrow keys. This includes new data structures for storing history entries, helper functions for managing history buffer, logic to handle escape sequences for arrows with careful serial input timing, and prototypes organized near the top. I'll need to integrate history recording after line input and enable browsing up/down through history while preserving current input state. Itâ€™s a detailed task requiring attention to input handling and buffer management!

**Implementing detailed history navigation logic**

I'm detailing how to save the current input line only once upon entering history navigation, and how to load previous and next history entries while carefully managing buffers and console display. I'll add functions to wait for input during escape sequence parsing to reliably capture arrow key presses, plus logic to ignore or consume unrecognized sequences quietly. Managing dynamic history storage with proper allocation and freeing will be critical, along with integrating history recording after command execution. This step-by-step plan sets up a robust CLI history feature!

summary.text:
**Designing shell command history support**

I'm planning extensive additions to shell.c to implement command history with navigation via arrow keys. This includes new data structures for storing history entries, helper functions for managing history buffer, logic to handle escape sequences for arrows with careful serial input timing, and prototypes organized near the top. I'll need to integrate history recording after line input and enable browsing up/down through history while preserving current input state. Itâ€™s a detailed task requiring attention to input handling and buffer management!

**Implementing detailed history navigation logic**

I'm detailing how to save the current input line only once upon entering history navigation, and how to load previous and next history entries while carefully managing buffers and console display. I'll add functions to wait for input during escape sequence parsing to reliably capture arrow key presses, plus logic to ignore or consume unrecognized sequences quietly. Managing dynamic history storage with proper allocation and freeing will be critical, along with integrating history recording after command execution. This step-by-step plan sets up a robust CLI history feature!

payload.output: Plan updated

payload.text:
**Adding per-process current working directory support**

I'm working on enhancing the process structure to track each process's current working directory (cwd), ensuring user processes inherit the shell's cwd. This involves updating the process struct with a cwd pointer, implementing getter/setter functions, modifying process creation to inherit parent's cwd or fallback to root, and updating the shell's cd command and file-open syscalls to use this per-process cwd. I'll carefully handle includes and forward declarations to avoid circular dependencies, add validation to setting cwd, and ensure fallback logic for processes created before the VFS is initialized.

summary.text:

I'm working on enhancing the process structure to track each process's current working directory (cwd), ensuring user processes inherit the shell's cwd. This involves updating the process struct with a cwd pointer, implementing getter/setter functions, modifying process creation to inherit parent's cwd or fallback to root, and updating the shell's cd command and file-open syscalls to use this per-process cwd. I'll carefully handle includes and forward declarations to avoid circular dependencies, add validation to setting cwd, and ensure fallback logic for processes created before the VFS is initialized.

payload.text:
**Designing process cwd management**

Iâ€™m working on adding functions and fields to manage each processâ€™s current working directory (cwd). This involves updating process struct with a cwd pointer, creating helpers to get/set it safely (falling back to root), updating process initialization and shell commands to track cwd correctly, and adjusting syscall file-open logic to use the process cwd. Iâ€™m also planning careful includes and forward declarations to handle vfs_node_t types without circular dependencies, aiming for a clean integration of cwd handling across process, shell, and syscall code.

summary.text:

Iâ€™m also planning careful includes and forward declarations to handle vfs_node_t types without circular dependencies, aiming for a clean integration of cwd handling across process, shell, and syscall code.

payload.text:
**Summarizing final response structure and content**

Iâ€™m organizing a clear final message summarizing modifications across files and line ranges, highlighting improvements like shell history, video terminal key handling, and working directory changes. Iâ€™ll include verifying instructions, mention not running automated tests, and suggest manual checks in a bullet format covering all key components and their locations.

payload.message:
**Shell History**
- Added non-blocking input helpers plus ESC-sequence handling in `src/sbin/shell.c:558-670`, so arrow keys no longer echo escape codes.
- Implemented a 20-entry circular history with saved-line restoration (`src/sbin/shell.c:733-845`) and record each submitted line before execution (`src/sbin/shell.c:250-272`), providing bash-style recall in the text shell.

**Video Terminal**
- Keyboard driver now queues VT100 escape sequences for arrows (`src/drivers/keyboard.c:22-190`), so both text and video shells see the same inputs.
- `atk_terminal` tracks history/saved lines per terminal (`src/atk/atk_terminal.c:95-974`), consumes arrow key sequences in `atk_terminal_handle_char` (`src/atk/atk_terminal.c:378-470`), resets navigation on clears (`src/atk/atk_terminal.c:522-525`), and clears history at reset/destroy (`src/atk/atk_terminal.c:599-746`).
- Backspace now walks into the previous line when needed (`src/atk/atk_terminal.c:1171-1190`), fixing the wraparound editing bug.

**Working Directory Inheritance**
- Processes carry a `cwd` pointer and inherit from their parent in `process_finalize_new_process` (`src/kernel/process.c:1073-1113`), with accessors declared in `include/process.h:30-65` and implemented at `src/kernel/process.c:2190-2235`.
- `shell_main` initializes its state from `process_current_cwd()` (`src/sbin/shell.c:250-263`), GUI shells do the same (`src/atk/atk_shell.c:69`), and `cd` now updates both the running process and the shellâ€™s owner process (`src/sbin/cmd_cd.c:5-35`).
- Syscalls resolve paths relative to the callerâ€™s cwd (`src/kernel/syscall.c:101-140`), so user programs inherit the shellâ€™s location automatically.

**Next steps**
1. Rebuild (`make`) and try arrow navigation plus history editing in the text shell.
2. Start video mode (`start_video`), open a terminal, and verify history/backspace behavior there.
3. `cd /mnt/disk1`, run `runelf ttf_demo.elf SF-Pro.ttf`, and confirm the relative path now works.

Tests not run here, so please exercise the flows above when convenient.

Iâ€™ll include verifying instructions, mention not running automated tests, and suggest manual checks in a bullet format covering all key components and their locations.

content.text:
**Shell History**
- Added non-blocking input helpers plus ESC-sequence handling in `src/sbin/shell.c:558-670`, so arrow keys no longer echo escape codes.
- Implemented a 20-entry circular history with saved-line restoration (`src/sbin/shell.c:733-845`) and record each submitted line before execution (`src/sbin/shell.c:250-272`), providing bash-style recall in the text shell.

**Video Terminal**
- Keyboard driver now queues VT100 escape sequences for arrows (`src/drivers/keyboard.c:22-190`), so both text and video shells see the same inputs.
- `atk_terminal` tracks history/saved lines per terminal (`src/atk/atk_terminal.c:95-974`), consumes arrow key sequences in `atk_terminal_handle_char` (`src/atk/atk_terminal.c:378-470`), resets navigation on clears (`src/atk/atk_terminal.c:522-525`), and clears history at reset/destroy (`src/atk/atk_terminal.c:599-746`).
- Backspace now walks into the previous line when needed (`src/atk/atk_terminal.c:1171-1190`), fixing the wraparound editing bug.

**Working Directory Inheritance**
- Processes carry a `cwd` pointer and inherit from their parent in `process_finalize_new_process` (`src/kernel/process.c:1073-1113`), with accessors declared in `include/process.h:30-65` and implemented at `src/kernel/process.c:2190-2235`.
- `shell_main` initializes its state from `process_current_cwd()` (`src/sbin/shell.c:250-263`), GUI shells do the same (`src/atk/atk_shell.c:69`), and `cd` now updates both the running process and the shellâ€™s owner process (`src/sbin/cmd_cd.c:5-35`).
- Syscalls resolve paths relative to the callerâ€™s cwd (`src/kernel/syscall.c:101-140`), so user programs inherit the shellâ€™s location automatically.

**Next steps**
1. Rebuild (`make`) and try arrow navigation plus history editing in the text shell.
2. Start video mode (`start_video`), open a terminal, and verify history/backspace behavior there.
3. `cd /mnt/disk1`, run `runelf ttf_demo.elf SF-Pro.ttf`, and confirm the relative path now works.

Tests not run here, so please exercise the flows above when convenient.
